Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: REU Site: A Distributed Network of Neuroscience Scholars
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the College of Wooster (Wooster, OH), Ohio Wesleyan University (Delaware, OH), Kenyon College (Gambier, OH) and Earlham College (Richmond, IN) will support 16 students for 9 weeks during the summers of 2016-2018. This project is supported by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI) in the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO) and the Directorate for Social, Behavioral & Economic Sciences(SBE). The research theme in the broad area of neuroscience include projects such as genetic model systems, neuromodulation, cellular responses to neurotrauma, rodent behavioral assessment, and cognitive and stress neuroscience. Participating labs are located in Biology, Chemistry, and Psychology departments. The diverse student research projects span the biological and social sciences, including gene expression studies during nervous system development in Drosophila, regulation of sodium channel expression in lamprey neurons, the effect of nitric oxide synthase on olfactory neurons in the fleshfly, computational modeling of the microglia-astrocyte-neuron system, and studies of action video games (AVGs) on executive functioning and perceptual ability. All of these projects contribute to important basic and applied research with the AVG project providing a thorough scientific investigation of effects and potential transfer of acquired skills to other contexts using a combined behavioral and psychophysiological approach. Students will participate in a full-time, mentored, team-based research project. A 3-day opening workshop will introduce students to the research theme, development of research plans, and data management. In addition, students will be trained on the responsible conduct of research. Participants will gather weekly either virtually or at one of the participating institutions for research updates, demonstrations, and professional development in writing CVs, attending and presenting at scientific meetings, local outreach, career planning, and applying to graduate programs. Students will present their findings at a research symposium at the conclusion of the program. Housing, a stipend, and meal and travel allowances will be provided. Students will be selected based on their interest in research, academic record, and other factors.

It is anticipated that a total of 48 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained over a period of 3 years. Students, especially those from groups that are typically underrepresented in science, are encouraged to apply. Students will learn how research is conducted, data analyzed, and results presented to both scientific and public audiences.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available at http://amyjostavnezer.voices.wooster.edu/nsf-reu/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Amy Jo Stavnezer at ajstavnezer@wooster.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Jennifer Yates at jryates@owu.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research: REU Site: A Distributed Network of Neuroscience Scholars

 

Collaboration is at the heart of how science is advanced. As is stated in the NSF Strategic Plan for 2014-2018, ?NSF places a high priority on cultivating strong communities of fundamental researchers and intellectual pioneers across the globe, working both as individuals and in a variety of collaborative ways.? The innovative approach of having this REU distributed across four regionally-located sites allowed both of these goals to be achieved. At each home institution, a pair of students worked on an authentic research project that advanced a scientific question and led to a variety of outcomes including presentations, publications and furthering the scientific question in each lab. Through the biweekly, in-person, consortial meetings, we exposed students, through explanation and demonstration, to multiple subdisciplines of neuroscience not available on any one campus, created a cohort of researchers exploring professional development and learning to communicate their science collaboratively and facilitated labs sharing knowledge, methodology, and equipment across institutions.

Across 3, 9-week summer experiences, we successfully immersed 44 undergraduates in a challenging, transformative research experience that allowed them to experience the nature and breadth of neuroscience research. The projects available to participants came from several subdisciplines/themes in Neuroscience including: Genetic Model Systems, Neuromodulation, Cellular Response to Neurotrauma, Rodent Behavioral Assessment, and Cognitive and Stress Neuroscience. Developing the next generation of scientists was our main goal and this was achieved as they engaged with hands-on, authentic research experiences, known to be a high-impact practice, practiced their public speaking skills, and many presented their work at regional and national conferences or became co-authors on publications. We had continued mentoring conversations throughout the summer, both within and across institutions, and discussed the development of each student?s personal repertoire of transferrable skills and knowledge. In addition to sharing their research data across the consortium at our final symposium, participants also shared their knowledge of neuroscience with community groups including children?s day camps, summer research camps, and elderly groups in care facilities.

We surpassed all of our 3-year recruitment goals, broadening access to science, with 31% of our participants identifying as an underrepresented ethnic/racial minority, 38% as first-generation, 56% were either first-year or sophomore level students, and 78% were female. Our participants rated their experiences as overall very positive, demonstrated significant gains in their ability to think/behave like a researcher and many plan to continue their research careers in graduate programs.  One-hundred percent of the participants report either ?a fair amount? or ?a great deal? of ?interacting with scientists from outside of your school? and ?feeling a part of a scientific community? and 93% report ?good? or ?great? gains in ?comfort discussing scientific concepts with others?, while and 100 % report ?good? or ?great? gains in ?comfort in working collaboratively with others?.  These students will enter the world of research well prepared to engage in the collaborative endeavors required to answer our pressing multi-disciplinary questions related to topics such as neurodegenerative disorders.
